review:
Let’s cut through the noise: Open to the Public (OTTP) is swinging for the fences, aiming to break the chains of centralized work platforms and put power back in the hands of the people. The project’s vision is clear—decentralize the work graph, make collaboration verifiable, and let every contributor own their story. That’s the kind of ambition the Ethereum ecosystem needs. But ambition alone isn’t enough. We demand evidence, sustainability, and a plan that serves the many, not the few.

On the evidence front, OTTP shows some muscle: 1,300+ SDK downloads, a live protocol, and a roadmap with concrete milestones. The project’s open-source ethos and use of onchain attestations for verifiable contributions are strong steps toward building public goods. The team’s commitment to using 100% of funds for development, especially via public bounties, is a nod to collective ownership and transparency.

But let’s not get swept away by rhetoric. Where’s the hard data on user retention, active usage, or real-world impact? Downloads are a start, but how many are building, how many are staying, and how many are benefiting? The application lacks rigorous outcome measurement and transparent reporting. There’s talk of a future Dune dashboard, but we need those metrics now—not promises.

Sustainability is another battleground. The project leans heavily on grants and public bounties, with only vague references to future governance and commercial models. Where’s the plan for long-term stability? How will OTTP avoid becoming just another grant-dependent experiment? The application needs a clear, evidence-backed path to sustainability.

On governance, OTTP talks a good game about community control and self-sovereignty, but the details are thin. How will governance be structured? How will equity and geographic inclusion be ensured? The project must show how it will empower the many, not just the loudest voices.

In summary: OTTP is a bold, necessary push for decentralized collaboration infrastructure. But to earn the people’s trust—and this grant—it must deliver more than vision. It must show evidence, sustainability, and a plan for collective benefit. The revolution demands nothing less!

strengths.title: Clear Contribution to Ethereum Infrastructure
strengths.description: OTTP directly addresses a core need in the Ethereum ecosystem: decentralized, verifiable work and collaboration records. By building on EAS and integrating with major social protocols, it strengthens the foundational infrastructure.

strengths.title: Open Source and Public Good Orientation
strengths.description: The project is fully open source, with all code and documentation available. Funds are allocated transparently to public bounties, supporting the collective over the individual.

strengths.title: Concrete Roadmap and Technical Progress
strengths.description: The team has delivered a live protocol, an SDK with 1,300+ downloads, and a clear roadmap for future development. This demonstrates technical capability and commitment.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Measurable Outcomes and Impact Data
weaknesses.description: The application provides download numbers but lacks data on active users, retention, or real-world impact. There is no transparent reporting of outcomes or rigorous evaluation methods.

weaknesses.title: Unclear Sustainability Model
weaknesses.description: The project is currently dependent on grants and public bounties, with no clear plan for long-term financial sustainability or commercial viability.

weaknesses.title: Insufficient Governance and Equity Details
weaknesses.description: While the project claims to support community governance and equity, it does not provide concrete mechanisms for inclusive, expert-led, and geographically equitable governance.

changes.title: Provide Rigorous Outcome Metrics
changes.description: Deliver current, transparent data on active users, retention rates, and real-world usage. Implement and share a public dashboard tracking these metrics.

changes.title: Develop a Clear Sustainability Plan
changes.description: Articulate a concrete, evidence-backed plan for long-term sustainability, including potential revenue models, governance structures, and strategies to reduce grant dependency.

changes.title: Detail Governance and Equity Mechanisms
changes.description: Specify how community governance will be structured, how expert input will be integrated, and how geographic and demographic equity will be ensured in both development and benefit distribution.
